isis.stitle: 7.3 Liter Diesel Engine Service (1991) - INJECTION PUMP, NOZZLES, FUEL FILTER, SUPPLY PUMP AND GLOW PLUGS - FUEL FILTER/WATER SEPARATOR ASSEMBLY REMOVAL AND REASSEMBLY (U-Haul Application Only) - DIAGNOSTICS

svcsubproc.title: Fuel Heater
svcsubproc.para: PROBLEM: Suspect inoperative fuel heater (circuit not closing).

step1.para: Disconnect harness lead at fuel heater.

step2.para: Connect a test lamp lead to the female socket of the fuel heater harness lead and ground the other end of the test lamp.
Turn ignition key to "ON" position and check for power.
Test lamp lights, circuitry to heater is OK.
Test lamp DOES NOT LIGHT, check the fuse.
- Fuse OK, repair wiring.
- Fuses not OK, replace fuse and recheck system.
- If the fuse opens again, repair wiring.

step1.para: Check fuel heater operation using a test lamp, as follows:

step2.para: Connect a test lamp in series with the fuel heater (one end to fuel heater and the other to the heater pin connector).
Turn ignition key to "ON" position.
Apply Freon, Freeze Spray or Dry Ice (only required if the engine is above 30° F) to the fuel filter/water separator header.

note.para: A heavy application of Freon, Freeze Spray or dry ice must be applied to the header to perform this test. A thick layer of "frost" must accumulate on the header to assure proper cooling. Freeze Spray is available through most electronics suppliers.

caution.para: USE FREON OR FREEZE SPRAY WITH CARE. AVOID CONTACT WITH SKIN AND EYES. WEAR SAFETY GLASSES. WEAR GLOVES IF HANDLING DRY ICE.

important.para: REGULAR ICE WILL NOT COOL THE ENGINE COMPONENTS ENOUGH TO PERFORM THIS TEST. DO NOT OPERATE THE ENGINE AT LEAST 4 HOURS PRIOR TO TESTING OR TO EXPEDITE THE HEATER TEST, COOL THE FUEL FILTER/HEADER ASSEMBLY IN A FREEZER AS FOLLOWS:

item.para: REMOVE THE FILTER/WATER SEPARATOR ASSEMBLY FORM THE ENGINE AND CAP ALL OPEN LINES AT THE INJECTION PUMP AND ENGINE.
DRAIN THE FUEL FROM THE FILTER USING THE DRAIN VALVE IN THE DRAIN BOWL.
CONNECT AN OHM METER TO THE FUEL HEATER CONNECTOR PIN AND GROUND ON THE HEADER/BASE.
PLACE THE FUEL FILTER/WATER SEPARATOR ASSEMBLY IN A FREEZER. THE OHM METER WILL INDICATE AN OPEN CIRCUIT WHEN THE HEATER HAS REACHED ITS ACTIVATION TEMPERATURE.

AFTER THE HEATER HAS BEEN ACTIVATED, QUICKLY REMOVE THE HEATER FROM THE FREEZER AND REINSTALL THE FUEL FILTER/HEATER ASSEMBLY TO THE ENGINE. TEST ON ENGINE USING THE TEST LAMP AS DESCRIBED IN STEPS 2 A-C.

svcsubproc.para: Test lamp lights, heater is operational.

note.para: Lamp should light within 10 minutes of proper cooling. If the engine is below 30° F the test lamp will be on all the time.

svcsubproc.para: Test lamp DOES NOT light, replace fuel heater.

note.para: Refer to disassembly instructions under "REASSEMBLY" in this section.

svcsubproc.title: Vacuum Switch

note.para: The vacuum switch activates a fuel filter restriction warning lamp, on the instrument panel, indicating the need for filter element replacement.

svcsubproc.para: PROBLEM: Warning lamp stays on (even with key on engine not running)

step1.para: Disconnect the vacuum switch wiring harness lead at the vacuum switch.
Turn the ignition key to " ON" position.
Lamp goes "OFF", replace the vacuum switch.
Lamp stays "ON", check for a short to ground in the wiring from the vacuum switch to the bulb.
Turn ignition key to " START", position.
Dash lamp "OFF" (does not light), replace bulb.

Dash lamp "ON"(lights up), remove vacuum switch lead and ground the lead. (Refer to Figure 9.15
).

step2.para: With ignition key in "ON", position, the dash lamp will either be "ON" or "OFF".
If dash lamp is "OFF", check the circuit for wiring.

step1.para: (Switch Operational Check)

step2.para: If dash lamp is "ON", remove the vacuum switch from the fuel filter header and apply a vacuum of 7 in. Hg. ± 1.5.

If vacuum does NOT hold, replace the vacuum switch. Refer to Figure 9.16
.

If vacuum does hold, verify that the switch is operational (comes on) at the correct vacuum specification. Refer to Figure 9.17
.

Check continuity by connecting a volt/ohm meter to the switch and applying 7 in. Hg. ± 1.5 vacuum, as shown in Figure 9.17
.
If no continuity at 7 in. Hg. ± 1.5 vacuum, replace the vacuum switch.

svcsubproc.title: Continuous Vent and Check Valve Assembly
svcsubproc.para: PROBLEM: Suspect blocked orifice at continuous vent.

step1.para: Disconnect fuel return hose at the vent fitting on fuel filter header.
Install a suitable length of test hose onto the vent fitting with open end of hose in a container (to catch fuel).
Start the engine.
Fuel flows into the container, the vent w/check valve is O.K. (Fuel leak-off rate is approximately 1 gal./hour).
If no fuel flow is observed, replace the continuous vent w/check valve assembly.

para.emph: PROBLEM: Suspect return fuel is drawn into the intake system.

note.para: This is possible if the check valve is defective and there is an inoperative fuel supply pump or if fuel inlet restriction is excessive.

svcsubproc.para: Test check valve operation as follows:

step1.para: Using a clean test hose, connect one end to the continuous vent and check valve fitting.
Blow into the open end of the hose and see if it holds pressure. You should feel resistance.
Check valve holds pressure, valve is OK.
Check valve DOES NOT holds pressure, replace vent and check valve assembly.

svcsubproc.title: Fuel Priming Valve Assembly

note.para: This component is used to charge the fuel system during production and bleed the fuel system of air during service.

caution.para: WHEN CRANKING THE ENGINE AND DEPRESSING THE FUEL PRIMING VALVE, CATCH ANY FUEL RELEASED FROM THE PRIMING VALVE IN A CONTAINER TO PREVENT THE POSSIBILITY OF FUEL CONTACTING ANY HOT ENGINE COMPONENT.

step1.para: Visually inspect for leakage at the header mating surface and at the fuel priming valve under the cap.
If leakage is not evident with the cap on, there is no need to remove it.

svcsubproc.para: If leakage is detected, install a new fuel priming valve assembly.

para.emph: Water to Fuel Probe and Water in Fuel Module (WIF)

note.para: The vehicle is equipped with a water in fuel warning lamp which is dash mounted. The lamp will light when the drain bowl is full indicating the need to drain the water and sediment from the drain bowl

svcsubproc.para: PROBLEM: Dash warning lamp stays "ON" (with ignition switch on).

step1.para: Drain the water separator drain bowl, as described under "MAINTENANCE" in this section.
Lamp goes "OFF", the system is operational.
Lamp stays "ON", proceed with Step 3.
Disconnect the water in fuel probe harness lead at the probe.
Lamp goes "OFF", remove the drain bowl from the fuel filter element and replace the water in fuel probe, located in the drain bowl.
Lamp stays "ON", proceed with Step 3.

svcsubproc.para: Disconnect the water in fuel (WIF) module from the cab wiring harness. Refer to CTS-4387 and 1 087 460 R2 for electrical circuit diagrams.

step1.para: Lamp goes "OFF", install a new water in fuel module (WIF).
Lamp stays "ON", look for a ground short in the wiring.

svcsubproc.para: PROBLEM: Suspect warning lamp does not light when the specified level of water is attained in the drain bowl.

step1.para: Turn the ignition key to the " ON" position and disconnect the water in fuel (WIF) module from the harness plug.
Dash lamp does not light

step2.para: Check for current at pin A of the WIF module harness plug socket.
If no current is present, check the fuse and circuitry.
If current is present, jump between pin sockets A and B with the key switch "ON".
If dash lamp lights, replace WIF module.
If dash lamp DOES NOT light, replace bulb or repair circuit.

step1.para:
Test wire continuity between pin socket D ( Figure 9.22
) and the harness connector for the probe (located on the fuel filter heater harness).

step2.para: If continuity is OK, check the water in fuel probe as follows:
Visually inspect for corrosion or erosion of the probe or fuel leakage, which may cause the circuit to NOT be completed. Correct leakage or replace the probe as required.

Check the probe for continuity as shown in Figure 9.23
. If continuity is NOT OK, replace the probe.
If continuity is NOT OKbetween pin socket D and the probe harness connector:
Repair or replace the wire.
